content.description: Australian dragon lizards have a <math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sex-determination system. The male genotype is homogametic (<math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), and the female genotype is heterogametic (<math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). However, all eggs incubated at temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tend to develop into females.
content.question: Which of the following best explains how the development of phenotypic female Australian dragon lizards with a <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype occurs when incubation temperatures are above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: Lizard embryos with a <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype cannot develop at temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

At incubation temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosomes are mutated into <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosomes.

At incubation temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, crossing over transfers genes from the <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome to the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome, producing females.

Incubation temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> inhibit the genes on the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome that produce proteins necessary for male development.

content.answer: Incubation temperatures above <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>32</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> inhibit the genes on the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome that produce proteins necessary for male development.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
